STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 10, 2021
Adam Baker
Wayne County DHHS - Northcentral
8625 Greenfield Rd.
Detroit, MI 48228
RE: License #: CP820201495
Wayne County DHHS - Northcentral
8625 Greenfield Rd.
Detroit, MI 48228
Dear Mr. Baker:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
12/01/2021. An Exit Conference was held with you on 12/7/2021. Due to the violations, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary
action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201495
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Adam Baker, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Wayne County DHHS - Northcentral
Facility Address: 8625 Greenfield Rd.
Detroit, MI 48228
Facility Telephone #: (313) 852-1709
Original Issuance Date: 09/20/1993
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site
Inspection(s):11/15/2021;11/16/2021;11/23/2021;11/24/2021;11/29/2021;11/30/2021;
12/01/2021

Reviewed
No. of current licensed foster homes 41 7
No. of homes pending licensure 11 3
No. of Foster homes closed since the last inspection 11 4
No. of Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 34 6
No. of Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 50 7

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

since last inspection 4 4

since the last inspection 53 6

METHODS OF INSPECTION – B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
No. of licensed foster homes 67 4
No. of unlicensed relatives homes 67 3
No. of independent living youth
No. of adoptive homes
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 3
Birth Parents
Independent Living Youth
Relatives 3
Adoptive Parents
Others (please identify person interviewed by role)
3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
Three of seven open foster home records reviewed did not
show timely compliance:
 In one record, the foster parent’s first aid recertification
due by 2/22/2021 was completed late on 6/22/2021.
 In a second record the foster parent’s first aid
recertification due by 8/30/2021 was not completed.
 In a third record the foster parent’s first aid recertification
was due by 11/24/2021. The agency provided
documentation showing it was completed late on
12/4/2021.
Repeat Violation- Interim-February 2021.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of seven open foster home records, and one of four closed
foster home records reviewed did not show compliance as
indicated by the rule. In the latter record, the foster home’s
license had expired when the recommendation for closure
occurred.
Repeat Violation- Interim-February 2021; Renewal-2019.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
4

One of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance: a relevant interview did not occur with the foster
parent related to an allegation. Additionally, documentation of
interviews of the children’s workers did not occur.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
Two of eight special evaluations reviewed showed the letter to
the foster parent was sent after more than 45 calendar days.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
(d):
One of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of the places of contacts and or
interviewer for all interviews. Nor was one relative’s
contact/interview documented in the methodology section of the
report.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2019.
(e):
Two of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance:
 In one special evaluation, the foster parent admitted to a
rule violation, and the special evaluation did not result
with a rule noncompliance.
5

 In the other the special evaluation did document an
interview with, or outcome of an interview the foster
parent related to an allegation by one of the foster
children. Additionally, other than documenting since this
was the second allegation, a corrective action plan is
needed; the analysis did not clearly document as to how
the worker arrived at the findings.
Repeat Violation- Interim- February 2021; Renewal 2019
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a right
to have his or her written response included as an attachment to
the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
(a):
Two of eight special evaluation records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation that the report
was provided.
 The other showed the report was provided 25 days after
its 1/7/2021 completion date.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2019.
(b):
One of eight special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance, as required by (b).
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Four of eight special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance, as required by (c).
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2019.
6

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
One of eight special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance, as required by (7).
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(i):
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s medical exam due by 5/15/2021 was completed 40 days
late on 6/24/2021.
(ii):
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s medical exam due by 6/23/2021 was completed 14 days
late on 7/7/2021.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.
R400.12417 Foster Parent Information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child.
(c)Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
7

(e)All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f)All known behaviors of the child.
(g)Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and foster family, including information about siblings who
do not reside in the foster home.’(j) Authorization to provide
routine and emergency medical care.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
information related to (a)-(h) was provided to the caregiver after
the child’s 4/15/2021 date of placement,
Repeat Violation -Interim-February 2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of five updated service plans reviewed was one and two
days late respectively.
Repeat Violation- Interim- February 2021; Renewal 2019.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
One of five initial service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of (h), as required by the rule.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any changes
made since the previous plan and which is to be used by the
foster parents.
8

One of 17 initial service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of a specific behavior management plan for the
child.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
Various foster care records reviewed did not show consistent
uploads of all case related documents and or report signature
pages.
Repeat Violation -Interim- February 2021; Renewal 2019.
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
Two of eight of open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance:
 One record did not show a May 2021 meeting.
 A second record did not show a February, March, or July
2021 meeting.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans.
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Four of 22 service plans reviewed were not signed by the birth
parent.
Repeat Violation- Interim- February-2021; Renewal 2019.
9

ISEP 6.49. Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation that an
8/10/2021 and 10/1/2021 medical passport for the child
was provided to the caregiver.
 A second did not show documentation that a 7/14/2021
and 9/21/2021 medical passport for the child was
provided to the caregiver.
 A third record did not show documentation of a quarterly
medical passport due for April, July, and October 2021.
Repeat Violation-Interim-February 2021; Renewal 2019.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
All case contacts must be documented in MISACWIS and
indicated in the service plan.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
that all foster care worker/supervisor meetings documented in
the social work contact section were indicated in the child’s
initial and updated service plans.
10

FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
-Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
-Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
-Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Two of 22 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 4/16/2021-5/15/2021 ISP. An FTM was
completed after the period on 5/26/2021.
 This same child’s 5/16/2021-8/13/2021 USP did not show
documentation of an FTM for the period. An FTM was
completed earlier than required on 6/28/2021.
Repeat Violation- Interim-February 2021; Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-8 Foster Care- Initial Service Plan.
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
One of five initial service plans reviewed was approved 22 days
late.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-8C Foster Care - Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement.
Signatures:
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
11

case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Five of 22 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 In four service plans, related to two child records, the
parent-agency treatment plan agreement (PATPA)was
either not signed by the caregiver or was signed more
than 30 days following the service plan/PATPA’s
approval date.
 A third record showed the PATPA for the child’s
2/17/2021-5/17/2021 USP was signed by the caregiver
and youth on 8/9/2021; more than 30 days following the
service plan/PATPA’s approval date.
Repeat Violation- Interim- February 2021; Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change:
Case Closure/ Change in placement:
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure or a placement change.
Four of six closed foster child records reviewed showed the
DHS-69 was completed late, with respect to the respective
child’s 10/20/2020; 3/22/2021; 4/15/2021 and 8/30/2021 case
closure date.
Repeat Violation- Interim-February 2021; Renewal 2019.
FOM 722-9 Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
One of 17 USPs was approved one day late.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2019
12

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation
 The agency was apprised it shall consistently assess the foster parent’s
weaknesses/limitations, as well as, report what the foster parent indicates in
this area.
R400.12326(1) (c) & (d) Borrowed home.
 Further consultation and technical assistance discussion was had with the
agency related to the rule and a letter it uses.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 As indicated above for R400.12326(1)(c) &(d).
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated abuse/neglect during this licensing
period.
There were four incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The first incident related to a 10/19/2020 intake of allegations that the foster mother
called her teenage foster daughter explicit and inappropriate language in the
presence of the foster father; the foster parents’ teenage daughter entered and
began hitting the youth; the foster mother and foster father allowed their daughter’s
actions and helped her by holding the teen foster child down. The investigation
substantiated the allegations and found the foster home in violation of the foster
parent qualification rule. Additionally, due to the investigation revealing another
person lived in the home, the foster home was found in violation of the reporting of
foster home changes rule. The foster child was removed from the foster home prior
to the completion of the special investigation. Revocation of the foster home’s
license was recommended.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation except, R400.12327(3) and R400.12327(6)(a), as cited in this
inspection report.
The second incident related to an intake of 2/17/2021 of allegations that the foster
mother grabbed the foster child’s arm, hit him on the arm, and bit it. Additionally, that
the foster father had to intervene to de-escalate the altercation. The foster mother
admitted to grabbing the foster child’s arm so as to get the foster child to release his
grip on another child’s arm. The foster mother admitted to biting the foster child’s
hand to get him to release the other child. The foster home was found in violation of
13

the behavior management rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the
foster home.
The agency adhered to departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation.
The third incident related to an intake of 4/19/2021 of allegations that the foster
parent locks the foster children in a basket when the children misbehave. The
special evaluation could not determine if the foster parent locked the children in a
basket. During the investigation the foster parent admitted she uses a stick to
threaten the children when they misbehave. The foster home was found in violation
of the behavior management rule; and a corrective action plan was developed with
the foster home.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation except R400.12327(3), and R400.12327(6)(c) as cited in this
inspection report.
The fourth incident related to an intake of 6/21/2021 of allegations that the foster
parent hit the foster child in the head, choked the child around the neck; and that the
child had a scar on his wrist and forehead. The special evaluation indicated an
inability to determine the validity of the allegations as reported by the foster child.
Due to prior allegations the special evaluation found the foster home in violation of
the behavior management rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the
foster home.
The agency adhered to all departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation except R400.12327(1)(c), R400.12327(5)(d) &(e);
R400.12327(6)(a)-(c) and R400.12327(7) as cited in this inspection report.
AND
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s February 2021 Interim
inspection where it received the following citations:
 R400.12212(3)(a)-Personnel record.
 R400.12306(4)-Application request.
 R400.12312(4) Foster parent training.
 R400.12324(8)-Reevaluation.
 R400.12326(1)(d)-Borrowed home.
 R400.12327(4) and (5)(f)-Special evaluation.
 MCL722.120(3) Act 116.
 R400.12328(2)(d)(iii) Foster home record.
 R400.12405(3)(e)-(g)-Change of placement.
14

 R400.12417(1)(c)-(h)-Foster parent information.
 ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS.
 ISEP 6.33(c)-Assessment and service plan content.
 ISEP 6.49- Medical passport.
 FOM 722-6B-Family team meeting.
 FOM 722-8C-Foster care-parent agency treatment plan & service
agreement.
 FOM 722-E-Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
 FOM 722-15- Case closure discharge document.
 FOM 723-Education services.
 SRM 200- Fingerprints.
The agency made significant progress with its corrective action plan but was not
totally successful with all of it. It received repeat violations in the following as
documented in this inspection:
 R400.12312(4) Foster parent training.
 R400.12324(8)-Reevaluation.
 R400.12417(1)(c)-(h)-Foster parent information.
 ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS.
 ISEP 6.33(c)-Assessment and service plan content.
 ISEP 6.49- Medical passport.
 FOM 722-6B-Family team meeting.
 FOM 722-8C-Foster care-parent agency treatment plan & service
agreement.
 FOM 722-E-Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The second correction action plan related to special investigation 2021C020041,
initiated 8/2/2021. The agency was found in violation of the following violations:
 R400.12405(3)(a)(b) & (3)(i), (ii) & (4)- Change of placement.
 722-8E- Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary (for
replacement)
 R400.12327(1)(a) &(b)-Special evaluation.
The agency submitted an acceptable action plan on 11/3/2021. The agency remains
incompliance with this corrective action plan.
It is noteworthy the agency has experienced a relocation. On April 27, 2021, the
agency moved from its prior Highland Park, location to its current Detroit, location on
Greenfield Road at Joy Road. The agency shares this location with the Department
of Health and Human Services’(DHHS) General Service Program which was already
the occupant of this building. The agency’s building space had been under
construction for a number of months. All construction with the exception of the
lobby’s reception area are complete. The latter is projected to be completed this
15

week. The agency has its own entrance, and as indicated, its own lobby and
reception area. The lobby has bathrooms and seating for clients and guests.
The agency’s office space consists of one main office utilized by the director; three
parent/child visitation rooms; two small conference rooms with a table and chairs;
one large conference, with a table and chairs; and 114 cubicles. A large number of
the agency’s 209 staff members have alternating in office days. Two-three staff
share a cubicle space, with only one person being onsite in that cubicle at a time per
the staffs’ alternating schedules. Each cubicle is equipped with desk, chair, and file
cabinet. Computers are available for all staff. There is ample storage space, printers
and xerox machines. The agency shares a breakroom/kitchen with the DHHS
General Service Program. It has a large secure file room. There is ample parking for
staff, clients, and visitors. The agency anticipates remaining at this location for a few
years.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts indicated this inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
December 9, 2021
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 10, 2021
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
16
